repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
I added tests for all versions of python to windows and solved some problems to let them work, but some don't:
2.7, 3.4 - since no suitable compiler version is installed
3.9 - inline, details: #3450, #4379
3.5 - one cpp-only test fails, [output](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4324#discussion_r709984107)

I also uncommented the coverage tests and added some code to the .sh to make them work. They work for a decent amount of time, which is the opposite of what was said in the comments.

If anyone wants to try to fix the problems and run 2.7 (and maybe 3.4), then you will need to use [this](https://stackoverflow.com/a/67642436), probably relying on both versions of [this answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/10558328).

comment_data.body: probably there's need to change the comment
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -196,15 +196,30 @@ jobs:
             backend: cpp
             env: { MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET: 10.14 }
 
+        exclude:
+          # fails github.com/cython/cython/issues/3450
+          - os: windows-2019
+            python-version: 3.9
+
+          # fails due to lack of a compatible compiler
+          - os: windows-2019
+            python-version: 2.7
+          - os: windows-2019
+            python-version: 3.4
+
+          # cpp specific test fails
+          - os: windows-2019
+            python-version: 3.5
+            backend: cpp
+
     # This defaults to 360 minutes (6h) which is way too long and if a test gets stuck, it can block other pipelines.
     # From testing, the runs tend to take ~20 minutes, so a limit of 30 minutes should be enough. This can always be
     # changed in the future if needed.
-    timeout-minutes: 30
+    timeout-minutes: 60

comment_data.body: `/W4` is recommended and gives an adequate number of warnings, but we can use `/Wall` + ignore unnecessary warnings (additionally to those `/wd`s)

+  fi
+

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  # /wd disables warnings
  # 4711 warns that function `x` was selected for automatic inline expansion
  # 4127 warns that a conditional expression is constant, should be fixed here https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4317
  # (off by default) 5045 warns that the compiler will insert Spectre mitigations for memory load if the /Qspectre switch is specified
  # (off by default) 4820 warns about the code in Python\3.9.6\x64\include ...
  WARNARGS="/W4 /wd4711 /wd4127 /wd5045 /wd4820"
```

Probably rather <1.16  that seems to be the version where they ended Py3.4 support.
```suggestion
numpy<1.16.0
```
Seems to be a general issue, though, and doesn't belong into a PR to make Windows builds work.
Otherwise a lot of windows cpp tests fail

comment_data.body:
here are all the use cases:

`CFLAGS="-O2 $DEBUG_INFO $WARNARGS $ALIASING"`
`CFLAGS="$NO_OPTIMIZATION $DEBUG_INFO" $PYTHON_DBG`
`CFLAGS="$NO_OPTIMIZATION $DEBUG_INFO $WARNARGS $EXTRA_CFLAGS"`

I do not see a better solution than adding `DEBUG_INFO` to `CFLAGS`, and then we will have to write like this:

`CFLAGS="$CFLAGS -O2 $WARNARGS $ALIASING"`
`CFLAGS="$CFLAGS $NO_OPTIMIZATION" $PYTHON_DBG`
`CFLAGS="$CFLAGS $NO_OPTIMIZATION $WARNARGS $EXTRA_CFLAGS"`

Not much better ..

comment_data.body:
> > I'd rather expect a change like this in a separate PR.
> 
> Well, if you want .. but it seems easier to fix failing tests right here, in the place where i add them

The problem is not new in this PR, is it? It's already there, and appveyor probably isn't happy with it either. Making it a part of this PR means that it will be buried under a heap of CI config related changes in the git history and for later generations of developers (and my future self and maybe yours), it will be difficult to understand why this was done at the time. Let's be nice to the people who live in the future.

comment_data.body:
> here are all the use cases:
> 
> `CFLAGS="-O2 $DEBUG_INFO $WARNARGS $ALIASING"`
> `CFLAGS="$NO_OPTIMIZATION $DEBUG_INFO" $PYTHON_DBG`
> `CFLAGS="$NO_OPTIMIZATION $DEBUG_INFO $WARNARGS $EXTRA_CFLAGS"`
> 
> I do not see a better solution than adding `DEBUG_INFO` to `CFLAGS`, and then we will have to write like this:
> 
> `CFLAGS="$CFLAGS -O2 $WARNARGS $ALIASING"`
> `CFLAGS="$CFLAGS $NO_OPTIMIZATION" $PYTHON_DBG`
> `CFLAGS="$CFLAGS $NO_OPTIMIZATION $WARNARGS $EXTRA_CFLAGS"`
> 
> Not much better ..

I think it's time to clean this up.

We can always add `$WARNARGS` and `$DEBUG_INFO` globally to `CFLAGS` since it doesn't hurt.

`-O2` can go to the end, then it's just `CFLAGS="$CFLAGS -O2" python setup.py `. We can then add `-O0` or `-Og` to `CFLAGS` by default.

AFAICT, that leaves two cases where we add a single additional option. I think that's more than bearable.

comment_data.body: Yes, I translated this incorrectly to the new syntax. But then it will be triggered only for cpython 3.10-dev (all non `-dev` versions are cut off by earlier `$PYTHON_VERSION == *"-dev"` and we add `COVERAGE = 1` only on cpython  3.7 and 3.9) is it the correct behavior?

comment_data.body: Originally (`"$BACKEND" != "cpp"`) the last conditional will run if `BACKEND == "c" / "c,cpp"`, now it will run only if `BACKEND == "c"`. @scoder was it an error in the original and therefore should we change this behavior back?
